6. Compliance Audits - At least once every 3 years, a person knowledgeable in the process
conducts a compliance audit. This is to determine if we have met our
obligations under applicable parts of 40CFR Part 68. Any deficiencies are outlined in our
compliance audits with a timeline of expected completion. Ideally, we approach these as safety deficiencies take a higher precedence than compliance or paperwork deficiencies.
7. Incident Investigations - If we have any incidents, we investigate them thoroughly to determine the cause and means to prevent it from occurring again. This facility has had no incidents to investigate in the previous 5 years.

D. Five Year Accident History
This facility has an excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries to any of its employees as a result of the RMP covered process. In addition, there have been no accidents resulting in releases of anhydrous ammonia with off-site consequences in the previous 5 years. Extensive programs and procedures are in place to maintain this record.

E. Emergency Response Program
As mentioned above, we are a non-responding facility and have met the requirements of an
Emergency Action Plan as well as coordinated efforts with our LEPC. Furthermore, we have
exercised our emergency notification procedures each calendar year.   

F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety Currently our facility meets current RAGAGEP and there are no plans currently in place to improve safety other than continually evaluating our current programs and efforts for continuous improvement. When newer RAGAGEP is published, our company will evaluate it at the time and determine if enhancements need to be made.

rd Assessment; however, it has been withheld from this Executive Summary as security-sensitive information as requested by EPA & DHS. 

Our Prevention program consists of 7 major parts.
1. Safety Information - This information outlines the overall hazards of our regulated substance,
anhydrous ammonia, includes our maximum intended inventory, safe upper & lower operating limits, provides equipment specifications, and lists any RAGAGEP
we have deemed appropriate for our facility.
2. Hazard Review - This is a systematic approach used to identify hazards associated with our
process that include human error and equipment malfunction as
well as safeguards needed to prevent that from occurring. It also includes steps needed to
detect and monitor releases.
3. Operating Procedures - We have developed specific operating procedures for our facility. Our
employees have been trained in the appropriate procedures for their respective duties. These procedures include, initial startup, normal and temporary operations, normal and emergency shutdown, startup after a normal or emergency shutdown, equipment inspections, and consequences of deviations and how to correct or avoid those deviations.
4. Training - Our employees are trained at least every 3 years on the respective procedures and
hazards associated with the process.
5. Maintenance - We have an established maintenance schedule that is based on RAGAGEP
including manufacturer's recommendations when available. In the
instances that those are unavailable, we use prior operating experience. We understand that
inspection and maintenance operators need further training, so we ensure each employee involved in the on-going mechanical integrity of the process has been trained in the hazards of the process, how to avoid or correct unsafe situations, and procedures applicable to the job tasks. When we do utilize contractors at our anhydrous ammonia facility, we ensure that the
contractors are trained and experienced to perform the task at

RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Introduction
Ottawa Cooperative Association is a supplier of fertilizer and other inputs to farmers. Bulk anhydrous ammonia is received via transport trucks and stored for the eventual sale to farmers. This facility is subject to the Risk Management Program rule as a Program Level 2 facility. This executive summary is our first means of communicating the risk to the public but also outlining our prevention program to further demonstrate we are a safe operator.

A. Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policy
We are a non-responding facility. However, we coordinate with the LEPC on an annual basis our
internal Emergency Action Plan and ensure we are still currently included in the community
emergency response program. Our Emergency Action Plan provides procedures for our employees to conduct in the event of an uncontrolled release or any other RMP reportable incident. We do our best to prevent accidental releases. We have well trained staff, established SOP's, and active and passive mitigation measures that act as additional fail-safe design.

B. Stationary Source & Regulated Substance Handled
This stationary source consists of bulk tanks and mobile nurse tanks of anhydrous ammonia. Exact quantities are withheld from this executive summary as a means of protection from potential malicious acts. The facility does hold in excess of the threshold planning quantity which subjects us to the RMP rule. The process is very simple. We receive anhydrous ammonia by transport truck. Store it in a bulk tank. And then transfer it to smaller, portable nurse tanks for farm use and application into the soil for crop nutrients.

C. General Accidental Release Prevention Program & Chemical Specific Prevention steps
Our overall Management System is laid out in our Risk Management Program. Overall
implementation is the responsibility of the Operations Manager. This facility has developed a worsecase and an alternative-release scenario as part of our Haza
